title: Ezra Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezra chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezra Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezra Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who was the king of Persia mentioned in Ezra Chapter 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyrus
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1 states that in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, the word of the LORD was fulfilled.

questions.question: According to Ezra 1:2, what was Cyrus charged by God to build?
questions.correctAnswer: A house at Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 says that the LORD charged Cyrus to build him a house at Jerusalem, which is in Judah.

questions.question: Where is the house that Cyrus was told to build located?
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 and 1:3 clearly state the house was to be built in Jerusalem, which is in Judah.

questions.question: Who was encouraged to go up to Jerusalem to build the house of the LORD?
options: All the people whose God is with them
questions.correctAnswer: All the people whose God is with them
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:3 invites anyone among the people whose God is with them to go up to Jerusalem to build the house of the LORD.

questions.question: What were those who remained in their places to provide to those going up to Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver, gold, goods, and beasts
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4 states that those remaining were to help with silver, gold, goods, and beasts besides freewill offerings.

questions.question: Who rose up to go to Jerusalem to build the house of the LORD?
options: Chief of the fathers of Judah and Benjamin, priests, and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: Chief of the fathers of Judah and Benjamin, priests, and Levites
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 says the chief of the fathers of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and those whose spirit God had raised went up to build the house.

questions.question: What did those who accompanied the builders strengthen their hands with?
options: Vessels of silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things
questions.correctAnswer: Vessels of silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:6 explains that those about them strengthened their hands with vessels of silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things.

questions.question: Who brought forth the vessels of the house of the LORD that Nebuchadnezzar had taken out of Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyrus the king
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:7 states that Cyrus the king brought forth the vessels of the house of the LORD that Nebuchadnezzar had taken.

questions.question: By whose hand did Cyrus bring forth the vessels of the house of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Mithredath the treasurer
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:8 says that Cyrus brought the vessels by the hand of Mithredath the treasurer.

questions.question: How many chargers of gold were brought back according to Ezra 1:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:9 lists thirty chargers of gold among the vessels brought back.

questions.question: True or False: Cyrus made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom to support the rebuilding of the house of God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1 states that Cyrus made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom regarding the rebuilding.

questions.question: True or False: The vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar were kept in the house of the LORD until Cyrus returned them.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:7 states Nebuchadnezzar put the vessels in the house of his gods, not the house of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Only the priests were involved in the effort to rebuild the house of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 mentions chiefs, priests, Levites, and all whose spirit God had raised were involved.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezra 1:11: 'All the vessels of gold and of silver were _______ and _______.'
questions.correctAnswer: five thousand and four hundred
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:11 states the total vessels of gold and silver were five thousand and four hundred.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezra 1:2: 'The LORD God of heaven hath given me all the kingdoms of the _______; and he hath charged me to build him an house at Jerusalem.'
questions.correctAnswer: earth
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 says the LORD God of heaven gave Cyrus all the kingdoms of the earth.

medium.title: Ezra Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezra Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezra 1, what biblical truth would you share about God's sovereignty and faithfulness?
options: God stirs the hearts of leaders to fulfill His promises
God abandons His people in captivity
God's promises depend on human strength alone
God does not intervene in political matters
questions.correctAnswer: God stirs the hearts of leaders to fulfill His promises
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1-2 shows that God stirred the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia to proclaim the rebuilding of the temple, fulfilling His word through Jeremiah. This demonstrates God's sovereign hand in fulfilling His promises despite circumstances.

questions.question: How does Ezra 1 teach about the importance of obedience to God's Word when rebuilding the spiritual life of the community?
options: The leaders and people responded by rising up to build the house of the LORD
The people ignored the call and stayed in Babylon
Only the priests were called to rebuild the house
The people demanded more gold before starting
questions.correctAnswer: The leaders and people responded by rising up to build the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 6 describe how the chief fathers, priests, Levites, and all whose spirit God raised responded in obedience by preparing to build the temple, showing the importance of faithful action when God calls.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with generosity in their church. According to Ezra 1, what biblical principle about giving can you share?
options: Generosity includes giving silver, gold, goods, and beasts willingly for God's work
Giving is optional and not necessary for God's work
Only priests should give for the temple
Generosity must be forced by the leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity includes giving silver, gold, goods, and beasts willingly for God's work
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4 and 6 emphasize freewill offerings and voluntary support from the people for building the house of God, teaching the value of willing generosity in serving the Lord.

questions.question: In the context of church leadership, what does Ezra 1 reveal about God’s role in raising up leaders for His purposes?
options: God raises the spirit of leaders to accomplish His will
Leaders must act independently without God’s guidance
Only kings can lead God's people
Leaders should focus only on personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: God raises the spirit of leaders to accomplish His will
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 says those whose spirit God had raised prepared themselves to build the temple, and verse 1 shows God stirred Cyrus’ spirit, illustrating God’s active role in raising leaders for His purposes.

questions.question: A church member feels discouraged about their small contribution to ministry. How does Ezra 1 encourage believers about the value of every gift?
options: All gifts, whether small or large, willingly offered are valuable
Only large gifts are recognized by God
Giving must be public to be accepted
Contributions are irrelevant to God's work
questions.correctAnswer: All gifts, whether small or large, willingly offered are valuable
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:6 highlights that all those around the builders strengthened their hands with silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things, besides what was willingly offered, showing the importance of every gift given with a willing heart.

questions.question: What does Ezra 1 teach about work ethic and integrity in serving the Lord through the example of Sheshbazzar?
options: Sheshbazzar carefully counted and handled the temple vessels with responsibility
Sheshbazzar kept the vessels for himself
The vessels were lost due to negligence
questions.correctAnswer: Sheshbazzar carefully counted and handled the temple vessels with responsibility
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:8-11 records how Sheshbazzar was entrusted with the temple vessels and numbered them, demonstrating faithful stewardship and integrity in handling God’s property.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezra 1, God’s plans can be fulfilled even through pagan rulers when He stirs their hearts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1-2 shows that God stirred the spirit of Cyrus, a pagan king, to proclaim the rebuilding of the temple, fulfilling His word, illustrating that God’s plans transcend human boundaries.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra 1 teaches that only the priests were encouraged to help in rebuilding the house of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:3-5 shows that not only priests but also the chief fathers, Levites, and all whose spirit God had raised were called to participate in rebuilding the house of the LORD, emphasizing communal involvement.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezra 1, the LORD God of heaven has given Cyrus all the ______ of the earth and charged him to build a house in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: kingdoms
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 states that the LORD God of heaven gave Cyrus all the kingdoms of the earth and charged him to build the house of God in Jerusalem, showing divine authority over earthly rulers.

questions.question: How does Ezra 1 encourage believers to support fellow workers in ministry?
options: By providing silver, gold, goods, and beasts to help those building the temple
By ignoring the needs of ministers
questions.correctAnswer: By providing silver, gold, goods, and beasts to help those building the temple
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4 instructs those who remain in their places to help the men going to Jerusalem with silver, gold, goods, and beasts, demonstrating the biblical principle of supporting those who serve God.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and reliance on God can be drawn from the people's response in Ezra 1?
options: They depended on God’s raising of their spirit to obey and serve
They trusted only in their own strength
They refused to serve without riches
They boasted about their own abilities
questions.correctAnswer: They depended on God’s raising of their spirit to obey and serve
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 shows that those whose spirit God raised prepared themselves to build the temple, indicating humble dependence on God’s enabling rather than self-reliance.

questions.question: Based on Ezra 1, what can we learn about gratitude and contentment in stewardship?
options: The people gave freely and joyfully of their silver, gold, goods, and beasts
The people demanded more before giving
The people were discontent and gave grudgingly
questions.correctAnswer: The people gave freely and joyfully of their silver, gold, goods, and beasts
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4-6 describes the willing offerings and strengthening of hands through gifts, reflecting gratitude and contentment in stewardship for God’s work.

questions.question: How does Ezra 1 illustrate perseverance through trials for the community of Israel?
options: Despite captivity, they rose up to rebuild the temple as God commanded
They gave up and stayed in Babylon
They fought among themselves and abandoned the work
They waited passively for better times
questions.correctAnswer: Despite captivity, they rose up to rebuild the temple as God commanded
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5-6 shows the leaders and people, after captivity, responded actively to build the temple, demonstrating perseverance and obedience amid trials.

questions.question: What does Ezra 1 teach about the importance of prayer and spiritual discipline in accomplishing God’s work?
options: The spirit God raised indicates a work of the Holy Spirit empowering obedience
Prayer was not needed because Cyrus made the declaration
Work for God depends solely on human effort
Spiritual discipline is irrelevant to rebuilding
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit God raised indicates a work of the Holy Spirit empowering obedience
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 states God raised the spirit of the leaders to go up and build the house, indicating divine empowerment through spiritual preparation often linked with prayer and discipline.

questions.question: According to Ezra 1, how should believers view possessions and wealth in relation to serving God?
options: As resources to be freely used for God’s work and offerings
As possessions to be hoarded selfishly
questions.correctAnswer: As resources to be freely used for God’s work and offerings
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 6 show that silver, gold, goods, and beasts were given freely for the temple, teaching stewardship and generosity with possessions to serve God.

hard.title: Ezra Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezra Chapter 1.

questions.question: In Ezra 1:1, it is mentioned that the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus. How does this divine action relate to the prophetic fulfillment mentioned in the same verse?
options: It fulfilled the word spoken by Jeremiah
It fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah about the Messiah
It was unrelated to any prophecy
It fulfilled the covenant with David
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfilled the word spoken by Jeremiah
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1 explicitly states that the LORD stirred up Cyrus's spirit to fulfill the word of the LORD by Jeremiah, showing a direct prophetic fulfillment.

questions.question: What is the significance of Cyrus proclaiming that the LORD God of heaven has given him all the kingdoms of the earth in Ezra 1:2?
options: It emphasizes God's sovereignty over earthly kingdoms
It is a statement of Cyrus's personal power
It is a common royal boast with no theological implication
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's sovereignty over earthly kingdoms
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 highlights that Cyrus acknowledges the LORD God of heaven as the source of his authority over all kingdoms, underscoring divine sovereignty in the ancient Near East context.

questions.question: Which group of people did the proclamation in Ezra 1:3 specifically invite to go up to Jerusalem and build the house of the LORD?
options: All who among his people whose God is with them
questions.correctAnswer: All who among his people whose God is with them
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:3 calls all those among the people whose God is with them to go to Jerusalem and build the house of the LORD, indicating a collective religious responsibility.

questions.question: According to Ezra 1:4, what were the men of each place encouraged to provide for those who would go to Jerusalem?
options: Silver, gold, goods, and beasts to aid the builders
questions.correctAnswer: Silver, gold, goods, and beasts to aid the builders
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4 instructs that those remaining in their places should help the builders with silver, gold, goods, and beasts, providing material support beyond freewill offerings.

questions.question: What literary device can be seen in the repeated emphasis on the building of the house of the LORD in verses 3 and 5?
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition for emphasis
questions.explanation: The repetition in verses 3 and 5 underscores the importance of rebuilding the temple, a key theme emphasizing restoration and covenant renewal.

questions.question: Who is identified in Ezra 1:5 as those who rose up to build the house of the LORD in Jerusalem?
options: Chiefs of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and all whose spirit God had raised
questions.correctAnswer: Chiefs of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and all whose spirit God had raised
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 lists these specific groups, showing a united effort among leaders and religious officials motivated by divine spirit.

questions.question: How does the mention of vessels of silver, gold, goods, and beasts in Ezra 1:6 reflect ancient Near Eastern practices of temple restoration?
options: It demonstrates the customary provision of material wealth for sacred rebuilding
It is a unique practice found only in Israel
It indicates tribute to Persian gods
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates the customary provision of material wealth for sacred rebuilding
questions.explanation: Ancient Near Eastern temple restoration often involved contributions of precious metals and goods, as seen in Ezra 1:6, aligning with cultural norms of dedicating valuable resources to religious projects.

questions.question: What is the significance of Cyrus returning the vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar as described in Ezra 1:7-8?
options: It symbolized restoration of Israel's worship and God's favor
It was a political strategy to control Judah
It was a Persian religious ritual
It was an act of theft
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized restoration of Israel's worship and God's favor
questions.explanation: Returning the temple vessels in Ezra 1:7-8 represents a restoration of the sacred worship and affirms God's ongoing covenant with Israel.

questions.question: Who was entrusted with counting the returned vessels according to Ezra 1:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Sheshbazzar, the prince of Judah
questions.explanation: Verse 8 details that the vessels were counted by Sheshbazzar, indicating his leadership role in the restoration effort.

questions.question: According to Ezra 1:9-10, what was the quantity of gold chargers brought back?
options: Four hundred and ten chargers of gold
Five thousand and four hundred chargers of gold
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty chargers of gold
questions.explanation: Verse 9 specifies thirty gold chargers, showing precise inventory of valuable items returned to Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is the total number of gold and silver vessels returned to Jerusalem as stated in Ezra 1:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Five thousand and four hundred
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:11 provides the total count of gold and silver vessels, emphasizing the scale of the restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Ezra 1:2 reflects a monotheistic worldview by attributing all kingdoms to the LORD God of heaven rather than to Cyrus himself.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse attributes Cyrus's authority to the LORD God of heaven, underscoring monotheistic belief in God's sovereignty over all earthly powers.

questions.question: How does the role of Mithredath in Ezra 1:8 demonstrate Persian administrative practices in managing conquered territories?
options: The treasurer managed valuable items and facilitated restoration efforts
He was a military commander enforcing Persian rule
He was a religious leader overseeing temple rituals
He was a scribe recording laws
questions.correctAnswer: The treasurer managed valuable items and facilitated restoration efforts
questions.explanation: Mithredath's role as treasurer shows the Persian practice of organized administration over treasures and resources in subject nations, facilitating restoration projects.

questions.question: Which theme present in Ezra 1 is foreshadowed by the return of temple vessels and the call to rebuild the house of the LORD?
options: Restoration and renewal of Israel's covenant relationship with God
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and renewal of Israel's covenant relationship with God
questions.explanation: The restoration of temple vessels and the call to rebuild signify renewal of God's covenant and worship, a central theme throughout Ezra and later Jewish history.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'whose spirit God had raised' in Ezra 1:5 in understanding leadership motivation?
options: It indicates divine inspiration as the source of leadership initiative
It means they acted independently without divine influence
It is a metaphor for military strength
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates divine inspiration as the source of leadership initiative
questions.explanation: The phrase underscores that the leaders' motivation to rebuild was prompted by God's spirit, emphasizing the theological theme of divine empowerment.

theological.title: Ezra Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezra Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What divine action is attributed to the LORD in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia according to Ezra 1:1?
options: The LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia
The LORD sent a plague upon the land
The LORD caused darkness over the earth
The LORD spoke directly to the people of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1 states that the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia to fulfill His word through Jeremiah. This demonstrates God's sovereign control over kings and nations (cf. Daniel 2:21; Romans 13:1; Proverbs 21:1; Isaiah 45:1).

questions.question: According to Ezra 1:2, what has the LORD God of heaven given to Cyrus king of Persia?
options: All the kingdoms of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All the kingdoms of the earth
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 says that the LORD God of heaven gave Cyrus all the kingdoms of the earth, highlighting God's sovereignty over all nations (cf. Psalm 22:28; Daniel 4:17; Revelation 11:15; Matthew 28:18).

questions.question: What charge did God give to Cyrus as mentioned in Ezra 1:2?
options: To build Him a house at Jerusalem
To gather the exiles in Persia
questions.correctAnswer: To build Him a house at Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:2 states that God charged Cyrus to build a house for Him in Jerusalem, pointing to God's plan for restoration and worship centered in the temple (cf. 2 Chronicles 36:23; Isaiah 44:28; Haggai 1:8; John 2:19-21).

questions.question: Who does Cyrus invite to go up to Jerusalem to build the house of the LORD according to Ezra 1:3?
options: Anyone among his people whose God is with him
The kings and rulers of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: Anyone among his people whose God is with him
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:3 invites 'anyone among you of all his people' whose God is with him to go to Jerusalem to build the house of the LORD, emphasizing God's calling on all His people to participate in His work (cf. Nehemiah 2:18; 1 Chronicles 28:10; Romans 12:11; Hebrews 3:6).

questions.question: What kind of support is to be provided to those who remain in their places from the men of their location according to Ezra 1:4?
options: Help with silver, gold, goods, and beasts
questions.correctAnswer: Help with silver, gold, goods, and beasts
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:4 commands that those who remain should help those going to Jerusalem with silver, gold, goods, and beasts, showing the communal responsibility to support God's work (cf. Exodus 35:21-29; 1 Kings 5:8-10; 2 Corinthians 9:7; Acts 20:35).

questions.question: Who rose up to go up and build the house of the LORD in Jerusalem as described in Ezra 1:5?
options: Chiefs of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and those whose spirit God had raised
questions.correctAnswer: Chiefs of Judah and Benjamin, priests, Levites, and those whose spirit God had raised
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:5 records that leaders from Judah and Benjamin, along with priests and Levites, and all whose spirit God had stirred, rose up to build the house, indicating divine empowerment in the work (cf. Nehemiah 2:18; 1 Chronicles 29:17; Acts 1:8; Philippians 2:13).

questions.question: How did those around the builders strengthen their hands according to Ezra 1:6?
options: With vessels of silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things
questions.correctAnswer: With vessels of silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:6 describes that the people strengthened the hands of those building with silver, gold, goods, beasts, and precious things, demonstrating sacrificial giving to support God's work (cf. Exodus 36:3-7; 2 Corinthians 8:1-5; Mark 12:41-44; Hebrews 13:16).

questions.question: What did Cyrus bring forth that Nebuchadnezzar had taken out of Jerusalem, according to Ezra 1:7?
options: The vessels of the house of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The vessels of the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:7 states that Cyrus brought forth the vessels of the house of the LORD which Nebuchadnezzar had taken, highlighting God's restoration of what was lost (cf. 2 Kings 25:13-17; Jeremiah 27:22; Haggai 2:7; Luke 19:38).

questions.question: Who was the treasurer that Cyrus used to bring forth the vessels and number them according to Ezra 1:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Mithredath
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:8 specifies that Mithredath the treasurer brought forth and numbered the vessels, showing the administrative order in God's plan (cf. Ezra 6:8; Nehemiah 5:14; 1 Chronicles 27:25; Acts 6:3).

questions.question: Who was the prince of Judah to whom the vessels were numbered and delivered according to Ezra 1:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Sheshbazzar
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:8 shows the vessels were numbered unto Sheshbazzar, prince of Judah, indicating leadership in the restoration (cf. Ezra 5:14; Zechariah 4:9; Nehemiah 12:1; 1 Chronicles 3:19).

questions.question: According to Ezra 1:9, how many chargers of gold were counted among the vessels?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty chargers of gold
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:9 lists thirty chargers of gold as part of the vessels, reflecting the preciousness and quantity of items restored (cf. Exodus 25:29; 1 Kings 7:50; 2 Chronicles 4:8; Luke 22:19).

questions.question: How many chargers of silver were accounted for in Ezra 1:9?
questions.correctAnswer: A thousand chargers of silver
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:9 mentions a thousand chargers of silver, indicating the abundant resources restored for the temple, consistent with Old Testament temple treasures (cf. 1 Kings 10:21; Jeremiah 10:9; Hebrews 9:4; Revelation 5:6).

questions.question: What total number of gold and silver vessels were brought up from captivity according to Ezra 1:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Five thousand four hundred
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:11 states that all the vessels of gold and silver numbered five thousand four hundred, emphasizing the scale of what was restored (cf. 2 Chronicles 35:3; Haggai 2:8; Revelation 21:21; Exodus 25:10-40).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God stirring up the spirit of a foreign king (Cyrus) to fulfill His word as seen in Ezra 1:1?
options: God exercises sovereign control over nations to accomplish His redemptive purposes
God only works through Israelite kings
God is limited to working within Israel's borders
God’s promises are dependent on human will alone
questions.correctAnswer: God exercises sovereign control over nations to accomplish His redemptive purposes
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:1 affirms God's sovereignty over all rulers, using Cyrus, a foreign king, to fulfill His promises, showing God’s providential governance over history (cf. Isaiah 45:1; Daniel 2:21; Romans 8:28; Psalm 22:28).

questions.question: How does the invitation in Ezra 1:3 to those 'whose God is with him' to rebuild the temple reflect the nature of true worship and community?
options: True worship involves a personal relationship with God and communal participation
Only the descendants of Levi can worship God
Worship is limited to sacrifices without community
Only kings and priests may build the temple
questions.correctAnswer: True worship involves a personal relationship with God and communal participation
questions.explanation: Ezra 1:3’s call to all whose God is with them highlights that worship is relational and communal, involving God’s people united in purpose (cf. John 4:23; Hebrews 10:25; 1 Corinthians 12:13; Psalm 133:1).
